(2) Abstract

HTML pages are for human users and describe a resource in structural terms (headings, lists, tables, …). For machine-based interaction, it is often useful to have more information about the meanings of application concepts. The Semantic Web is a research program and set of standards for trying to specify these meanings. One goal is to enable data published on the Web to be easily interlinked.



Adding Meaning to HTML

Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(4) Problem of Semantics: Syntax vs. Meaning

  • Computation is great at syntax and grammar
    • All X are Y
  • Take the following syllogisms
    • All dogs are mammals
    • All cats are bipeds
    • All Lady Gagas are cats
  • Logical syntax does not necessarily take into consideration meaning
    • The sum of the angles of a triangle is equal to the color red
    • While grammatically correct this makes no sense


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(5) Adding Meaning to HTML

  • HTML describes structures in a very general way
    • HTML elements describe logical page structures such as headings, lists, tables, …
    • useful for dynamic and adaptive page rendering, but not for understanding contents
  • Good HTML may have more information available
    • classes in HTML elements may represent underlying concepts (CSS may use this)
    • HTML containers (e.g. lists) may represent aggregation of some basic information items
  • Very good HTML
    • standard class names and some guidelines for using them
    • some rules for using combinations of particular class names


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(6) Plain HTML

<div>
  <h1>Spoon, Deerhunter, and Micachu and the Shapes at The Fox Theater</h1>
  <p>Tuesday 13 April 2010 at 7:30pm</p>
  <div>
    <div>The Fox Theater</div>
    <div>
      1807 Telegraph Avenue<br/>
      Oakland, CA 94612
    </div>
    <div>(510) 302-2277</div>
  </div>
</div>

(7) Good HTML

<div class="event">
  <h1 class="title">Spoon, Deerhunter, and Micachu and the Shapes at The Fox Theater</h1>
  <p class="when">Tuesday 13 April 2010 at 7:30pm</p>
  <div class="where">
    <div class="venue">The Fox Theater</div>
    <div class="address">
      <div class="street-address">1807 Telegraph Avenue</div>
      <span class="city">Oakland</span>, 
      <span class="state">CA</span>
      <span class="zip">94612</span>
    </div>
    <div class="phone">(510) 302-2277</div>
  </div>
</div>
  • event-good.html (line 7-20)


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(8) Very Good HTML: Microformats

<div class="vevent">
  <h1 class="summary">Spoon, Deerhunter, and Micachu and the Shapes at The Fox Theater</h1>
  <p class="date">
    <abbr title="20100413T1930Z" class="dtstart">Tuesday 13 April 2010</abbr> 
    at <span>7:30pm</span>
  </p>
  <div class="location vcard">
    <div class="fn org">The Fox Theater</div>
    <div class="adr">
      <div class="street-address">1807 Telegraph Avenue</div>
      <span class="locality">Oakland</span>, 
      <abbr class="region" title="California">CA</abbr> 
      <span class="postal-code">94612</span>
    </div>
    <div class="tel">(510) 302-2277</div>
  </div>
</div>
  • event-microformat.html (line 7-23)


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(9) Microformats

  • A microformat is an agreed-upon set of names for HTML element classes, and rules for using them
  • Microformats do not add anything new to HTML: they are a way of using HTML
  • Microformats are good for small, commonly encountered bits of data
    • Calendar events [http://microformats.org/wiki/hcalendar], contact info [http://microformats.org/wiki/hcard], licensing info [http://microformats.org/wiki/rel-license], etc.
    • nofollow [Web Search; nofollow (1)] is a microformat too
  • Creating new microformats involves reaching consensus in the microformat community
    • This takes time and effort, so there are lots of "draft" microformats and few actually in use
    • Only the most common kinds of data get standardized


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(10) Very Good HTML: RDFa

<div class="vevent">
  <h1 class="summary">
    <span about="http://dbpedia.org/resource/Spoon_%28band%29"
          typeof="http://purl.org/ontology/mo/MusicGroup">
    <span property="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name">Spoon</span></span>, 
    <span about="http://dbpedia.org/resource/Deerhunter"
          typeof="http://purl.org/ontology/mo/MusicGroup">
      <span property="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name">Deerhunter</span></span>, 
    and 
    <span about="http://dbpedia.org/resource/Micachu"
          typeof="http://purl.org/ontology/mo/MusicArtist">
      <span property="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name">Michachu</span></span>, 
    and the Shapes at The Fox Theater
  </h1>
  <p class="date">
    <abbr title="20100413T1930Z" class="dtstart">Tuesday 13 April 2010</abbr> 
    at <span>7:30pm</span>
  </p>
  <div class="location vcard">
    <div class="fn org">The Fox Theater</div>
    <div class="adr">
      <div class="street-address">1807 Telegraph Avenue</div>
      <span class="locality">Oakland</span>, 
      <abbr class="region" title="California">CA</abbr> 
      <span class="postal-code">94612</span>
    </div>
    <div class="tel">(510) 302-2277</div>
  </div>
</div>
  • event-rdfa.html (line 7-35)


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(11) RDFa

  • RDFa is another approach to adding meaning to HTML
  • Unlike microformats, RDFa adds some new attributes to HTML
  • While microformats are defined for specific kinds of data, RDFa can be used for any kind of data
    • No need for wide consensus
  • But RDFa is a little more complicated to use than microformats


Adding Meaning to HTML Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(12) Using Microformats & RDFa with Operator

  • Operator [https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/4106] is a Firefox add-on for interacting with microformats and RDFa
  • It looks for microformat and RDFa classes and attributes and does intelligent things with them
  • Its functionality can be extended with user scripts
  • Try it on our example [src/event-rdfa.html], or Yelp [http://www.yelp.com/biz/top-dog-berkeley], or Best Buy [http://products.semweb.bestbuy.com/y/products/9811355/]


Semantic Web & Linked Data

Semantic Web & Linked Data Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(14) Linked Data Principles

  1. Use URIs as names for things.
  2. Use HTTP URIs so that people can look up those names.
  3. When someone looks up a URI, provide useful information, using a standard data model.
  4. Include links to other URIs, so that people can discover more things.


Semantic Web & Linked Data Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(15) URIs as Names

  • Recall [Web Foundations (URIs & HTTP); Resources & Representations (1)] that a URI identifies an abstract resource
  • This means that a URI can identify any abstract concept, not just web pages
  • The Semantic Web is mainly about how to assign URIs to any concept
  • DBpedia [http://dbpedia.org/] is a project creating URIs for every topic in Wikipedia
    • Spoon: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Spoon_%28band%29 [http://dbpedia.org/resource/Spoon_%28band%29]
    • Mysticism: http://dbpedia.org/resource/Mysticism [http://dbpedia.org/resource/Mysticism]
  • But anyone can create URIs for concepts
    • Panthera tigris: http://lod.geospecies.org/ses/QMUrD [http://lod.geospecies.org/ses/QMUrD]
  • Multiple people or groups can create URIs for the same concept
    • All the URIs for Panthera tigris [http://sameas.org/html?uri=http%3A%2F%2Flod.geospecies.org%2Fses%2FQMUrD]


Semantic Web & Linked Data Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(16) Semantic Web Data Model

  • The standard data model defined by Semantic Web standards is called RDF
    • Stands for Resource Description Framework
  • Data in RDF is just lists of statements:
    • Spoon is a music group
    • Spoon is named "Spoon"
    • Spoon has a member Britt Daniel
  • A statement consists of three parts: [subject] [predicate] [object]
    • [Spoon] [is a] [music group]
    • [Spoon] [is named] ["Spoon"]
    • [Spoon] [has a member] [Britt Daniel]


Semantic Web & Linked Data Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

Practical Applications Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

(21) Enhanced Search Results

  • When indexing [Web Search; Indexing (1)] web pages, search engines can parse microformats and RDFa to add details to result pages
  • Instead of trying to guess at address, prices, or reviews, they can access this data directly
  • Doesn't affect ranking, only the display of results
    • So there's no point in putting in fake/spam data


Practical Applications Gregory Jonason
Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

      Practical Applications Gregory Jonason

      (24) Government Data

      • Government data sets are a good use case for the Semantic Web
        • Government data is intended to be made available to the public
        • Publishing on the web is a great way to make data widely available
      • Data sets are more useful when they can be linked and merged
      • Linking and merging before publishing to some centralized place creates a bottleneck
      • In theory, the Semantic Web can enable linking and merging of data sets published independently
      • Theory being tested at data.gov.uk [http://data.gov.uk/]


      Gregory Jonason
      Jack J. Valenti School of Communication      , University of Houston Semantic Web, Linked Data & Microformats

      (25) Conclusions

      • Standard vocabularies for describing data can make data more useful
      • There are various approaches for using such vocabularies on the web
      • It is not clear yet which approaches will become most widely used
      • Nevertheless this is an important area to watch
